div1.p: Komp finds great value Carter's abstracts of malaria literature.

div1.head: Letter from W.H.W. Komp to Henry Rose Carter, January 24, 1922
div1.opener:
Mal
Abstract
OFFICE OF
SANITARY OFFICER IN CHARGE
MISSISSIPPI COASTAL DISTRICT
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Gulfport, Miss.
Box 65, Brewton, Ala.
Jan. 24, 1922.
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
In answer to your recent letter please let me say
that the great value of the present method of making abstracts
of malaria literature, to us who are unfamiliar with foreign
conditions, is in the translating of these conditions into terms
of our own experience. Your remarks on the findings of the
authors are really the most enlightening parts of the abstracts.
I can truthfully answer your question, therefore, by saying that
the simple abstract, without comments, will not “do as well”
as an abstract with your comments. In fact, I'd prefer the
comments without the abstract. I sincerely hope that you will
not find it too much of a burden to continue making these
abstracts, as they are of special interest to me since being
transferred to research work with Dr. Barber.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, W. H. W. Komp.
Assistant Sanitary Engineer,
U. S. Public Health Service.
